job_title: Revenue Management Assistant Manager in Singapore
pros: - Not much, except that UPS is an internationally recognized brand and that the Singapore office is a regional role that is less execution focused
cons:
- After restructuring, both teams have become very lean. Depending on which function you are in, you may find the work either very boring or overwhelming. There is hardly anything in between.
- Career development opportunities are limited to a select few that the top management has identified. Most people who reach managerial levels stay on and generally do not leave which means limited opportunities for promotion, rotation and growth. 
- The company's focus is on the US and EMEA market instead of APAC even though there's where most of the growth and revenue is coming from. This means they devote less resources developing the people and markets here. You will generally find that the APAC region is more interested in cost-cutting and improving productivity and less on anything else.

review_title: a US driver earns more than a UPS APAC marketing supervisor
pros:
Region office - give exposure to people around the world
Fast promotion within 1 or 2 years
Company provide staff bus and OT pay (cap at $15/hr)
No gender discrimination- quite a few female hold high level position
cons:
HR is incredibly incompetent and inflexible, they introduced a TLA system so that employees can voice out their concerns on the company but the company listen and don't act. So TLA is for show. 
HR also failed in computing employees' annual pro-rated leave- even primary school students can do better than them.
Turnover rate is very high among higher management and non management. Many political moves are made under the table. Non management job hop because of low pay. Higher management had to tender their resignation because of back stabbing. Most of the local higher managements resigned and were replaced by foreigners. 
UPS gives very low salary compared to their peers. A supervisor earns about 3k. Bonus payout is 0.4 month and Annual increment is about 3%
Recently the company is struggling but they still set up a special team to 'interview' each and every employee on their job scope - wasting resources.
They also set up a special team to negotiate in buying over TNT but the negotiation didn't went through because of European union's law. How can the specialized team didn't thoroughly do their homework on the legal process on merging? The loss in negotiation results in a few hundred million loss - means smaller bonus for employee

Next her emails did not address me by name just said Hi.
I never received a formal offer of employment till I joined inspire of multiple requests.
Upon joining I realized all the HR processes are so time consuming, late arrival of ID card , delay in receiving other HR related documents.
I sense UPS lacks professionalism and works like a primitive organization.
The culture of people working inside is very rigid, strong hierarchy felt and are very repulsive to changes. It wasn't a pleasant experience for me and others who left the organization for similar reasons.

review_title: First job after graduating from college
pros: Family culture and everyone is helpful and friendly to each other and there is zero politics on the non management level which was fantastic. Canteen food is cheap so you can save some money on lunch. There is shuttle bus provided to mrt stations hence good work life balance as bus leaves at 6pm. Managers are very willing to teach and impart knowledge. Generally a good MNC with good benefits and lives up to its name. Low turnover as a result of good and healthy culture.
cons: None really. I loved the company and truly regretted leaving. One of the best firm I have worked for and met the best people there.

pros: The pay is excellent .health care is 100 % paid with 100 %coverage...with exception to eye and dental which is about 70%..coverage...pension is outstanding..full package with wages and benefits is worth 130,000 yearly..without a college education I am grateful for the standard of living UPS HAS AFFORDED ME AND MY FAMILY!...and with 27 years of service I now get 6 weeks vacation with 8 sick days..and 9 paid holidays...we work hard like many people in the work force but we are well compensated!.
cons: The only con is while your children are young you give up a lot of family time..I never got to watch my kids play sports and missed a lot of their growing years...the job can be hard on your home life but if you can make it through those years you and your family will enjoy the financial freedom that UPS provides...and now I look forward to a prosperous retirement!...so hang in there all you young drivers...

review_title: Pay part time supervisor More ($28 hr. )
pros: Flexibility . Education assistance .
cons: Pay suck long hours Higher management doesn’t pay part time Supervior enough. Every one is getting paid 20.00 hour they don’t give a competitive wage increase inside union employees get free benefits but pt sups get no cost of living increase . Pt sups are struggling to make ends meet but someone off the street makes a dollar less and pt sup are extremely over worked. The part time supervisor are use by full time management and not compensated well at all. Beware of full time manager they will try to get over on you in more ways than you think . Cover Up!!!

pros: Decent pay, easy to learn
cons: Micromanaged but yet incompetent training. I worked holiday extra help. Delivered in my own vehicle. Training was online only except a brief overview with driver on how to deliver and sort. Had to use own vehicle. Given a new huge neighborhood route to learn each day other than than originally agreed to. There was not enough time in the day to complete them all after the 3rd day of them adding new routes.. Equipment given to scan packages was a cell phone with an app to scan. Took at least 1 minute to look up package and address. My duaghter had to help me at one point and my husband had to help. . Phone did not charge enough. One shift I lost charge and had to call supervisor to get help. Went out late at night to finish my shift with a driver. He had a scanner and the packages scanned quickly. Supervisor was upset that it was taking so long. I explainrd the area we were in was rural and that we had to go uo to houses with locked gates. He rode with me and timed me then tweaked how long it should take. It took a lot longer than they had estimated. I had another full time job in the evenings and told them I could not do it all. They did not respect it. So after 2 weeks I quit.

pros: Decent pay, i started around 20. Some down time. Work isn’t that hard.
cons: EVERYONE IS IN CLIQUES! It’s like highschool but worse. Seniority is everything there, there are mean crazy women that been there for 20+ years that will make ur life hell. Management doesn’t do much to help this. They will say they are going to to do something and never will. You will get told to do other peoples work. Some supervisors and bosses flirt and sleep with eachother and other employees which leads to favoritism and a really u comfortable work environment. Honestly it’s just not worth it. Oh and they rly don’t base raises off performance. They just bump you up a few measly cents once a year and they will give the ppl with the highest seniority the most. You will NEVER GET POSTITIVE VIBES! Just save yourself the headache . Oh and if ur In the office, you will without a doubt get fat lol.

pros: This is a job that I’ve always wanted and the only pro I can say is the benefits are amazing!
cons: They overload all the associates with a ton of work in the short amount of time that we are there. The managers are extremely rude, intimidating, harassing the associates and constantly being wrote up for the smallest things, even though the union book has certain things that the managers are writing us up for are not supposed to be used against the union associates per the union contract. All the managers care about is holding union associates “accountable” but they do not want to hold their supervisors accountable for anything! This is not a job for someone who has mental issues or anyone that cannot pick up over 70 pounds. For the past year this building has made a lot of associates not want to be at the warehouse. The morale and the environment is horrible. There’s never any appreciation, hey good job, keep up the good work, not even a good morning!!! Like I said, all they care about is writing union members up and holding them accountable. This is the worst company I’ve ever worked for hands-down. And to become a driver forget about it, because you’re going to Boot Camp and I mean that in all aspects. Also, if you have any medical conditions, and you have a doctors notes, might as well just quit or not apply because they do not except any doctors notes.

job_title: Seasonal Private Vehicle Driver in Portland, OR
pros: The hourly pay plus overtime. Plenty of exercise!

Some of the big truck drivers were very grumpy and they all had their own methods that they all thought were best. You have to be very flexible, accurate, quick and have a good attitude in all types of weather conditions. No regular restrooms to use (especially during Covid for women!) Many male drivers had urinal jugs.

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Paid to workout or you can stand still and move periodically if you’ve worked here long enough. Insurance through the union after 9 months of breaking your body in. 1 free water bottle a day in the summer.
cons: I can’t even begin to share all the cons about working for UPS. It doesn’t matter how hard you work, this company is part of a union that will be re-negotiating its contract within the next few months. But, considering how much UPS doesn’t care about their Union employees, I don’t see things getting any better. They WILL drop your pay (by $3.50 for me personally) with no warning, multiple times a year. They used to let me double shift for OT but now it’s been forbidden for all, since Jan 1st. Leaving EVERYBODY, broke, desperate, and begging for more hours, so don’t get too comfortable. All I can say is don’t expect to be able to support yourself financial by working here only on 19 hrs a week, it will drive you insane thinking things are improving, just to have it all ripped out from underneath you.

review_title: Lowered payrate, disrespectful management, horrible workplace atmosphere
pros: The hours are great if you are good with overnight shifts.
cons: They bait and switch by advertising $24 an hour while really paying $16 an hour with a weekly "bonus" that covers the difference as long as you are on time for your shift and don't take any days off. After a few months they of working there they changed the pay rate to $19 an hour with no bonus. The management is rude and disrespectful and generally treats everyone like trash. If you do have to call in for any reason they will treat you like a criminal. If you catch covid they will try to make you go back to work even if your still obviously contagious with no regard for the safety of the other employees. In the time I was there I watched more people come and go than any other job I've worked at (me among them) and nearly every one of them was because of management or from injuries because of the horrible attention to safety.

Instead of equal distribution of work, if you make a point to be a good worker, your effort will be taken for granted.

pros: handler include: Flexible scheduling: Many package handling jobs offer part-time or flexible scheduling options, which can be ideal for students or those with other commitments. Physical activity: Package handling jobs often involve a lot of movement and can be a good way to stay physically active. Job security: With the increasing reliance on e-commerce and home delivery, the demand for package handlers is likely to remain strong in the coming years. Entry-level position: Package handling jobs are often entry-level positions, which can be a good way to gain experience and start a career in logistics or supply chain management.
cons: Physical demands: Package handling jobs can be physically demanding, and may not be suitable for individuals with certain health conditions or physical limitations. Repetitive motions: The repetitive motions involved in package handling, such as lifting, carrying and sorting packages, can lead to strain injuries and musculoskeletal disorders. Work in a warehouse environment: Package handlers often work in a warehouse environment, which can be noisy, dusty, and may be maintained at less than optimal temperatures.

pros: UPS is probably the best large company to work for. The brand is recognized everywhere, and this gets you in a lot of customer doors. The people (for the most part) are all bought in on being a team, and the amount of resources you have available to you is pretty endless. A good company to start a career with, and excellent benefits long term if you stick with it.
cons: The training that is provided can leave a lot to be desired. There is a lot of movement and change in leadership, which can stunt your growth, even if you adapt quickly. Selling a service can be difficult, and it's more difficult when you don't have completely comprehensive training to support it. You are at the mercy of the service around the world doing their jobs properly. If a package is late, damaged, or lost, you will usually be the one to catch the most heat from the customers. There are a lot of resources available to you to fix problems, but there is nothing absolute that you can do to fix many customer complaints. It's a fine line to walk, but it is doable. It just takes a lot of creativity, time, and tenacity.

The Pay scale here is variable based on the time of year/season; at this time of the year, employees appear to get paid the most and are offered a huge amount of Overtime opportunities! I feel that I am heard at this company, and well respected by all the managers and supervisors in my sector. Communication here at UPS is massive, and I really enjoy it! --5 hours of labor considered full-time employment
cons: --Overtime for In-season is supposedly mandatory, though I have seen quite a few employees still take their Saturdays off. --this job has a variable pay scale, which may affect your overall annual income. --the job only guarantees 3.5 hours of labor per day; as previous point states.

pros: None that I can think of at present.
cons: Companies like UPS are the reason why financial inequality exists, and why it's so bad today. UPS doesn't care one bit about how much experience you have. You can have 20 years' experience and they still only set their wage rates to levels from at least a decade ago, despite the fact that the second quarter of this year, 2022, they posted profits over $24 billion. They also use recruiting outfits, many owned by people from India, and are probably paying these foreigners $40 to $60 per hour off your back, instead of paying you, the American citizen, a more-appropriate wage. I find this completely unacceptable behavior, by any company, and it's exactly this kind of disrespect for American workers that creates paycheck to paycheck living situation, forcing Americans to rely on credit and placing themselves in debt. These big-wig billionaires have the audacity to sit there talking about financial inequality and how it can be fixed, but they conveniently don't bother to recognize the fact that it's companies are GREEDY and not paying people more when they can very easily afford to. This amounts to nothing more than indentured servitude, which as far I'm concerned, has been the new form of slavery which has been taking place for decades now. They've been freezing wage increases all that time, and meanwhile they're pulling in billions. It's absolute disgusting!

The issue with this is that they tell you you are hired only for a local HR rep to tell you on your hiring day that you were "accidentally hired due to their outsourced employees giving wrong information." I filled out all new hire paperwork, which took a couple of hours, and even set a start date. Telling somebody on the morning of their start date that they are not hired is not only unethical, but immoral. To UPS, you are just a number and they couldn't care less about you.

job_title: UPS Feeder Driver in Middletown, PA
pros: Brand new trucks which is amazing to have. You can get lots of hours when you have a bid for the week which is only available in the busy season from September to January. They pay time and a half after 8 hours every shift which is amazing. You can easily make $125-$148K/year if you can put up with being on call after the busy season and are putting hours in.
cons: Without seniority and being a part of union you are going to be on call. They only provide you with a 2 hour window to come in to work. They call you at the times that you have not slept yet which provides a dangerous work situation. You are expected to conform to their needs without saying anything and your needs are not valued. It makes you feel that you are just a number who is replaceable. Drivers need to have their rest. You are always in a different truck and majority of the trailers that they rent are always broken. If you start in the busy season then you cannot qualify for benefits or health insurance until the season is over. We were told that we would get health benefits after the first 30 days from our start date, but then they changed it to receive benefits after the busy season. So you work 4-5 months without benefits. After the busy season they go off of punch ins for each shift that counts a day towards the benefits.

pros: Ample opportunities to learn, grow and get exposure to higher level executives. The Territory AE role is challenging -- typically a patch is 200+ accounts AND there's a lot to learn initially about UPS services & supply chain solutions. Good news is they bring you along at the right pace and in the right way if you're hard working, genuine and personable with a backbone.
cons: All hands on deck from Thanksgiving through Xmas so no vacations as UPS operations needs everyone. Still kinda cool as salesperson to work in operations and/or deliver packages for perspective and Sales VP's are right next to you. Other con would be luck of the draw on territory assignments, when one opens that's yours for better or worse so some luck towards success and promotion are at play. Everything with management is negotiable if approached in a smart, strong, win-win approach. Overall a truly solid company and an excellent outside sales role.

I was forced to work on LABOR DAY, and was told I was not going to receive holiday pay because I had not been at the company 90 days. The woman who ran training said she had just earned her 4th vacation week after being at the company 20 years. In my 3 weeks I was one of 5 people to walk out mid shift. They had me and two others doing the work meant for 7, and were upset things were not getting processed fast enough. They also did not allow us to have phones in the warehouse because of the product that was in there, but all the construction workers were on their phones right next to me. The worst job I have worked, would never ever go back to this company. Oh, and my starting pay was $12 an hour and I had a bachelors degree.

When I could not come back after surgery because I couldn't lift 70 lbs alone, I asked for a transfer to an office position. I was denied. Because I couldn't lift 70 lbs. I asked for them to show me all those women in their mid 70's that they lift 70lbs alone. I was told not to be ridiculous and those women can't lift that. I read the policy verbatim. I never went back. It could have been great, just don't get hurt

They have no respect for what their employees have accomplished during covid, and it's a slap in the face to be required to return to the office when I have successfully launched a global program in the last year. UPS also has a culture of fearing your management, so no one will speak up honestly about how this will negatively affect their team. The top down management style is absolutely terrible and no way to keep employee morale up. If I could give them negative stars, I would. Bad leadership. Unable to handle employee requests. Glacial pace. Management doesn't develop talent.

review_title: extremely poor communication and training from mgmt
pros: the job itself isn't bad at all. easy and relatively mindless as long as you stay organized. nobody looking over your shoulder, micromanaging or pushing you to work faster. relatively few daily interactions with other people once you leave the hub facility, so good job for introverts and people who work well autonomously. freedom to develop your own systems and deliver at your own pace. decent pay + mileage and lots of room for overtime during peak season.
cons: seasonal job, so everyone is fired in January. communication from management is a joke. the onboarding process was a mess. training was abysmal, nearly non-existent. most of the training and useful information came from other PVD drivers who'd worked prior seasons. supervisors, managers and HR people could hardly be bothered to give more than one word answers or look you in the eye. despite job postings indicating immediate hiring, it was about a month from application to actual start date. "official" start date per UPS corporate communications during onboarding turned out just to be driving to the hub facility to show ID to an HR person. after that it was another week before having to go to a different (farther) hub for training, but that too turned out to just be filling out some badly xeroxed paperwork, which included test questions that we had not yet been trained on the answers to. when asking supervisor on duty about these test questions, her answer was "oh it doesn't matter, we shred those and throw them in the trash the minute you're all fired at the end of the season." cool. finally, a week later I was finally contacted to train on a route, which was with a PVD only in their second week on the job. Two days later I was training another PVD on my route. So yeah, training, not so much. Luckily its an easy gig. Despite being told the job went through mid-January, there was no work for PVDs after Christmas, even though they strung us along every few days with "we will send out communication this evening about tomorrow" but they never did.

review_title: Would love to work there again
pros: I love UPS. Worked in the warehouse as small sort. Fast-paced days so it works for my attention span. Great mobility if you want it and the union support is great as well.
cons: If you have short attention span and that line breaksdown the package count you'll get bored and antsy. Other than that, I have no cons and hope to start working there again soon now that pandemic is over.

pros: Good benefits and nice people
cons: HUGE. Hard to be heard.

pros: -Coworkers are awesome. Favorite part of the job. -(Most) of the managers are really cool too. -Union protected. Had a situation where upper management (more on them later) fired a coworker of mine. He was back in 2 days thanks to the union. -A lot of the time, it really is like getting paid to work out. Not the easiest work, but it's not an awful step into being more active (I've been losing weight pretty consistently).
cons: -Upper management. If this were a month or two into my tenure, I'd put this in the Pros section. The original "head" manager was really cool and I liked him. He left and got "temporarily" replaced with a suit, and he's been changing things left right and center. Making metro work in load every night during seasonal was a pretty bold and dumb move on his part (and the reason why someone got "fired"). He's also gotten other suits involved like an "efficiency expert" who I'm sure knows what he's doing on paper, but his suggestions will probably drop worker happiness. Can't have multiple people per truck (so we talk to each other less) and insists we use rollers (which are pretty good until the belt stops, then they're literally the worst). It's just cramping the otherwise chill vibe. -Pay. Starts at $15.50. Amazon'll kick your butt in their warehouse, but at least you'll be making $17 for your troubles. -Non-seasonal hours are laughable. Outside of seasonal, it's almost impossible to make a living off of this job alone. Either you work 2 jobs, or just quit and get a job that works you 5-8 hours per day consistently. As we wrap up seasonal, you can expect 3-4 hour days, and 20 hours MAX per week. If you're lucky. Or you can work 6 days and guarantee 20 hours, but then you're working 6 days in a physically demanding job. -High turnover. I've personally seen at least 10 faces come and go during a 2 month stretch in seasonal, and apparently there's been more people I don't know about who've quit. If UPS could keep people, then the job would be dummy easy and we wouldn't feel like we're understaffed almost all the time. -Benefits. UPS totes some of the best benefits for a part-time employer. They also tote the longest probation period for said benefits I've ever heard. You have to work here 9 months in order to get access to your benefits. Considering the pay + hours scenario, I doubt a lot of people get the benefits. Heck, I'm probably not gonna get the benefits, and I actually like this job!

review_title: Extremely inefficient and you'll need the health benefits with this job
pros: Good benefits and you'll need them since UPS works you to death and awful pay. Tuition reimbursement.
cons: Constant OT. You can rarely plan on doing anything in your personal life. They ask you for more overtime (10-12 hour work days), ask you to come in on your off days too. The systems they use are dated and extremely inefficient and awful. For a company this size, you would think they have their stuff together. When you question current practices or provide advice from someone who does it daily, they shrug and say "this is how we've always done it." They do not do anything to hold shippers accountable for the needed information to clear shipments outside of returning it if we can't get the info. Therefore, everyone who has worked the shipment basically wasted their time trying to clear it. Their processes, again, are awful. You have to constantly fix other problems with shipments due to others mistakes. Training is a joke for what you really have to do in this job. They do not prepare you enough for the onslaught of work and things you are required to know. If you get this job, be ready to be tied to your desk with 2 breaks during the 10-12 hour day (or more). By the time you're off, you won't want to do anything for your personal life. Go to bed and wake up for the same stuff the following day.

pros: 18-25k steps a day. Feeling of accomplishment after a long hard days wok.
cons: Whatever you imagine it would be like to work for UPS as a driver just erase that thought. Everything from the hire process to collecting your pay when the hours are off. It’s almost unbelievable what I experienced as a 22.4. It's important to know the difference between a RPCD and a 22.4. The 22.4 position was created to be a hybrid inside/driver position but instead became a way for UPS to just have cheaper delivery drivers. You don't have the same overtime protection as the RPCDs so they work you like a dog and the pay is lower for doing the same work. It’s not the company you want to be apart of.  UPS was private until 99. Ask any old timer and they will tell you thats when it was good.  At UPS the management which are “employees of UPS” and everyone else who is union (inside warehouse workers and drivers). UPS management are not union. You have two forces working side by side. The union workers just want to do a fair days work for a fair days pay and go home. The union workers are great. Never met anyone I didn’t like. The management at least at the center I work at I reserve judgment because there under pressure to meet numbers but I witness shady behavior many times when I was there from lying on my packet to trainers teaching the methods but not applying the methods to cut time to show the route can be done at "said" time. If management wants you out they will play games. Numerous times my diad would malfunction. I was told one time to just use your cell phone!? After working for sometime I was told I needed to fill out another application because there system had me coded in a different position.  Expect long hours and a bricked out truck. A big red flag was when drivers are expected to show up early off the clock to organize there trucks. Technically thats the the pre loaders job but since they're constantly quitting or being understaffed it falls on your shoulders. Whats sad is people do work off the clock because they just want to make there day smoother. You are monitored the whole work day via telematics.  Every stop is recorded and you have to follow in order ignition, handbrake, pull in left mirror seat belt and bulk head door grab package, close door and repeat. If you waiver on this the telematics will report. Management secretly will following you to see if you’re following the methods. Sometime you catch them and blow there cover lol.  Finding addresses in complete darkness I found very challenging.  Peeing in a bottle 5 to 10 times a day is absurd but everyone does it. Having equipment failures from Diad (hand held computer)malfunctions to bulkhead door fob not working and Orion zig zagging across you route in a way that doesn't seem the most efficient. My biggest challenge was the multiple high rise's apartment complexes I had that are a nightmare especially when there are no package lockers or you cant get access to the building and you have 200 plus stops and 1 stop might have 60 plus separate packages over 10 floors with oversized items and daylight is running out with residential stops left to complete. The sun is your best friend. As soon as the sun sets it’s a whole different animal. You will have a flash light and headlamp to add in the steps of each stop. Unfortunately in todays job market people are desperate for decent paying jobs so UPS is hiring constantly and it becomes a meat grinder of new hires willing to  give it a go. If it was great UPS wouldn’t have a revolving door like they do.  All that being said I think it really depends on the city and the UPS center you are working at. If you’re not young I would not bother and if you’re young the stress and physical  repetitive work  overtime will have you feeling old. What good are benefits if you cant see your family and what good is a pension if your body is too busted up and cant enjoy retirement.  In my opinion based on my experience the juice isn’t worth the squeeze.  I did witness some amazing talented drivers who make the work look easy. It's not for everyone. Good luck!

They paid overtime- the key to make money

1st The late start - As the driver you have to wait for the next day air shuttle and it comes most of the time late. It makes your day really long. 
2nd Really physically hard jobs - most of the people won't last a year. They stock your truck so much that you wanna quit just seeking it. 
3rd They pay preloaders so little for one the most physically strenuous jobs up there which results in really high turnover of workers. Which leads to a lot of miss-loads and more headaches and job for you as the driver. 
 4th They don't start to pay enough the first year drivers. But that's their strategy to make the money - make the young drivers work as much as possible and lay off the senior drivers for a day or two cause they make a big money
5th - 1 week paid vacation after 1 year hard work is not enough ---every other better company starts at least with 10 days of PTO

job_title: Part Time Package Handler in Buffalo, NY
pros: Some of the management and fellow workers do actually treat you like a human.
cons:
-The pay for part timers is insulting for the amount of labor in the warehouse. It is basically hard labor/ backbreaking work for very low pay.
-The work is extremely dangerous with little regard for your safety except for the company mentioning safety. It is not a safe work environment at all. There are multiple slip/trip fall hazards, crushing hazards in tight spaces, and falling object hazards.
-The equipment is outdated and the management is only concerned with numbers.
-Training is minimal and there are no safeguards for packages falling onto employees off the chute. Ergonomics is non-existent.
-The work environment is toxic with little respect for fellow employees and harassment is second nature to some. The environment is absolutely unprofessional. There is little to no respect for fellow employees.
-U stands for "United", which this place is most definitely not. This place is nothing more than a glorified US based sweat shop.
